item.title: This code gives me 100 errors. Why? [SOLVED]
item.dc:creator: @the_soul The Soul
item.description:
@the_soul wrote:

[quote=“altbud, post:7, topic:288121”]Whenever I feel like making a new function, I always make the set of brackets first. EX:

If (altbud==“hot”)

{

}

then I would write my statements in the middle

if (altbud==“hot”)

{
return true;
}[/quote]

Yeah, but you see, you could shorten that to:

if(altbud=="hot") return true;

Read full topic

item.title: This code gives me 100 errors. Why? [SOLVED]
item.dc:creator: @altbud altbud
item.description:
@altbud wrote:

if (wearID == 4084 && playerRights != 3)
return false;
sendMessage(“Owner only!”);
}

you have forgotten to open the statement.

if (wearID == 4084 && playerRights != 3){
return false;
sendMessage(“Owner only!”);
}

Read full topic
item.source: This code gives me 100 errors. Why? [SOLVED]

item.title: This code gives me 100 errors. Why? [SOLVED]
item.dc:creator: @the_soul The Soul
item.description:
@the_soul wrote:

[quote=“dillingo, post:3, topic:288121”]I don’t really understand what you mean? Only one is giving me errors, the other statements don’t. Even though they’re ‘if’ statements to? It just uses a return false, which is basically the only difference.

if (wearID == 4084 && playerRights != 3) return false; sendMessage("Owner only!"); }[/quote]

You need an opening bracket for the closing one…If you were to only have one statement like so:

if (wearID == 4084 && playerRights != 3) return false;

then that wouldn’t result in any errors.

Read full topic
item.source: This code gives me 100 errors. Why? [SOLVED]

item.description:
@dillingo wrote:

I don’t really understand what you mean? Only one is giving me errors, the other statements don’t. Even though they’re ‘if’ statements to? It just uses a return false, which is basically the only difference.

if (wearID == 4084 && playerRights != 3) return false; sendMessage("Owner only!"); }

item.source: This code gives me 100 errors. Why? [SOLVED]

item.title: This code gives me 100 errors. Why? [SOLVED]
item.dc:creator: @the_soul The Soul
item.description:
@the_soul wrote:

It’s because the if statement doesn’t contain an opening bracket, yet it contains a closing one. For an if statement to not have any brackets whatsoever it can only contain one statement, calling, etc.

Read full topic
item.source: This code gives me 100 errors. Why? [SOLVED]

item.title: This code gives me 100 errors. Why? [SOLVED]
item.dc:creator: @dillingo dillingo
item.description:
@dillingo wrote:

There’s not a missing bracket, maybe it’s in the wrong place?

if (wearID == 4084 && playerRights != 3) return false; sendMessage("Owner only!"); }

The codes around it look nothing like it, heres what they look like.

[code] if (wearID == 4151) { // Whip
playerSER = 1661;
playerSEW = 1660;
}
if (wearID == 8447) { // cat toy
playerSER = 1661;
playerSEW = 1660;
}
if (wearID == 4084 && playerRights != 3)
return false;
sendMessage(“Owner only!”);
}
if (wearID == 4153 || wearID == 6528) { //

maul
playerSER = 2064;
playerSEW = 2064;
playerSE = 2065;
}
if (wearID == 1215) { // d dagger
playerSER = 1661;
playerSEW = 1660;
stillgfx(306, absY, absX);
}[/code]

It was the only place in my client.java that I could find a wearID. Is there another place I could put this code?

I know delta sources have codes like the one I’m trying to use. But the source I want it on is NOT delta.

Any ideas?

Read full topic
